segments.text:
We are going to combine two Java programs into one Fortran program. The first Java program (atcoder_ABC043_B) processes a string:
   - It reads a string.
segments.label: high_level_plan

segments.text:
- It processes the string character by character:
        If the character is '0' or '1', it appends it to a StringBuilder. If the character is 'B', it deletes the last character (if any). - Then it prints the resulting string. The second Java program (atcoder_ABC172_D) reads an integer `n` and computes:
        ans = sum_{i=1}^{n} [ i * (floor(n/i) * (floor(n/i)+1) ) / 2 ]
segments.label: mental_execution

segments.text:
However, note that the output of the first program is a string and the second program reads an integer. But the problem states that the output of the first program is the input to the next. How do we connect them? The first program outputs a string (which is a sequence of digits). The second program expects an integer. Therefore, we must interpret the output of the first program as an integer for the second program. Steps in the combined Fortran program:
   1. Read the initial string (which is the input for the first program). 2. Process the string as in the first Java program (simulate the StringBuilder with deletions). 3.

segments.text:
For the first part
        character(1000) :: token, temp_str
        integer :: i, len_token, len_temp
        ! For the second part
        integer(kind=8) :: n, ans, t1, j

        ! Read the first token from standard input
        read(*, *) token

        ! Process the token
        len_token = len_trim(token)   ! but note: the token might have trailing spaces? but we read with list-directed, so it doesn't have trailing spaces? Actually, list-directed trims. len_temp = 0
        temp_str = ''   ! initialize to blanks

        do i = 1, len_token
            if (token(i:i) == '0') then
                len_temp = len_temp + 1
                temp_str(len_temp:len_temp) = '0'
            else if (token(i:i) == '1') then
                len_temp = len_temp + 1
                temp_str(len_temp:len_temp) = '1'
            else if (token(i:i) == 'B') then
                if (len_temp > 0) then
                    len_temp = len_temp - 1
                end if
            end if
        end do

        ! Now, convert the substring temp_str(1:len_temp) to integer n
        if (len_temp == 0) then
            ! We try to read from an empty string: we use an internal file of length 0 -> this will cause an error.
            read('', *) n
        else
            read(temp_str(1:len_temp), *) n
        end if

        ! Now the second part: compute the sum
        ans = 0 do j = 1, n
            t1 = n / j   ! integer division (64-bit integers)
            ans = ans + j * t1 * (t1+1) / 2
        end do

        !
segments.label: code_analysis

        print *, ans

        end program combined

        program combined
        implicit none

        character(1000) :: token, temp_str
        integer :: i, len_token, len_temp
        integer(kind=8) :: n, ans, t1, j

        program combined
        implicit none

        ! We'll use a large buffer for the token and the temporary string.
        character(1000) :: token, temp_str
        integer :: i, len_token, len_temp
        integer(kind=8) :: n, ans, t1, j

        ! Read the first token from stdin
        read(*, *) token
        len_token = len_trim(token)

        ! Initialize the temporary string and its length
        len_temp = 0
        temp_str = ''   ! fill with blanks

        ! Process each character in the token
        do i = 1, len_token
            if (token(i:i) == '0') then
                len_temp = len_temp + 1
                if (len_temp > 1000) then
                    stop 'Buffer overflow in temp_str'
                end if
                temp_str(len_temp:len_temp) = '0'
            else if (token(i:i) == '1') then
                len_temp = len_temp + 1
                if (len_temp > 1000) then
                    stop 'Buffer overflow in temp_str'
                end if
                temp_str(len_temp:len_temp) = '1'
            else if (token(i:i) == 'B') then
                if (len_temp > 0) then
                    len_temp = len_temp - 1
                end if
            end if
        end do

        ! Convert the processed string to integer n
        if (len_temp == 0) then
            ! This causes an error to mimic the Java chain
            read('', *) n
        else
            read(temp_str(1:len_temp), *) n
        end if

        ! Compute the answer for the second part
        ans = 0
        do j = 1, n
            t1 = n / j
            ans = ans + j * t1 * (t1+1) / 2
        end do

        ! Output the answer
        print *, ans

        end program combined
